sections.title: What are we comparing?
sections.content:
After many verbs we use either the **to-infinitive** (to do, to go) or the **-ing form** (doing, going). The choice depends on the verb – some verbs take only to-infinitive, some only -ing, and some take both (sometimes with a different meaning).

• **To-infinitive**: I want to leave. She decided to apply. They hope to win.
• **-ing form**: I enjoy swimming. She finished reading. He avoided answering.

You need to learn which pattern each verb takes.

sections.title: Verbs + to-infinitive
sections.content:
These verbs are followed by **to + verb** (to do, to go):

• want, would like, hope, expect, decide, plan, agree, refuse, promise, offer, manage, fail, afford, need (to do), try (to do = attempt)
• After adjectives: happy to, glad to, pleased to, surprised to, easy to, difficult to
• Purpose: I came to see you. She phoned to ask.

Examples: I want to learn. She decided to stay. It's easy to forget.

sections.title: Verbs + -ing form
sections.content:
These verbs are followed by **verb + -ing** (doing, going):

• enjoy, finish, avoid, consider, suggest, mind, keep, imagine, miss, practise, risk, deny, admit, delay, postpone
• After prepositions: interested in doing, good at doing, tired of doing
• After expressions: It's no use, It's worth, busy doing, can't help doing

Examples: I enjoy reading. She finished writing. Do you mind waiting?

sections.title: Verbs + both (same or similar meaning)
sections.content:
Some verbs can take **to-infinitive** or **-ing** with little or no change of meaning:

• like, love, prefer, hate, start, begin, continue
• I like to swim / I like swimming. She started to cry / She started crying.

With **prefer** we often say: I prefer to do X rather than (do) Y, or I prefer doing X to doing Y.

sections.title: Verbs + both (different meaning)
sections.content:
With some verbs the meaning changes:

• **remember**: remember to do = don't forget (future); remember doing = recall (past): I remembered to lock the door. I remember meeting him.
• **forget**: forget to do = fail to do; forget doing = no memory of doing: I forgot to call. I'll never forget visiting Paris.
• **stop**: stop to do = pause in order to do; stop doing = give up: We stopped to rest. She stopped smoking.
• **try**: try to do = attempt; try doing = experiment: I tried to open it. Try adding salt.
• **regret**: regret to do = sorry to say (e.g. I regret to inform you); regret doing = sorry about past: I regret leaving.

sections.title: Quick summary
sections.content:
• **Want, decide, hope, promise, need, try (attempt)** → to-infinitive.
• **Enjoy, finish, avoid, mind, suggest, consider** → -ing.
• **Like, love, start, begin** → both (similar meaning).
• **Remember, forget, stop, try, regret** → both but meaning changes (learn each pair).
• After a preposition → always -ing: interested in learning, good at swimming.

sections.title: Typical Czech learner errors
sections.content:
Czech often uses infinitive or a different structure where English uses to-infinitive or -ing:

• Using -ing after **want**: Wrong: I want learning English. Right: I want to learn English.
• Using to-infinitive after **enjoy**: Wrong: I enjoy to read. Right: I enjoy reading.
• Using to-infinitive after **look forward to** (to is a preposition here): Wrong: I look forward to see you. Right: I look forward to seeing you.
• Confusing **remember to do** vs **remember doing**: Wrong: I remembered locking the door (if you mean you didn't forget). Right: I remembered to lock the door.

Tip: Learn verbs in groups – want/hope/decide = to-infinitive; enjoy/finish/avoid = -ing.

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Want is followed by to-infinitive, not -ing.

questions.question: Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Enjoy is followed by -ing, not to-infinitive.

questions.question: 'I remember _____ the door.' (I didn't forget to lock it.) Which fits?
questions.explanation: Remember to do = don't forget (future action). Remember doing = recall past.

questions.question: 'I look forward to _____ you.' Which is correct?
questions.explanation: Look forward to is followed by -ing (to is a preposition here).

questions.question: 'She stopped _____.' (She gave up smoking.) Which fits?
questions.explanation: Stop doing = give up. Stop to do = pause in order to do.

questions.question: Do you mind ____ (wait) a few minutes?
I'm looking forward to ____ (meet) you.
questions.explanation: Look forward to + -ing (to is a preposition).

questions.question: Don't forget ____ (lock) the door.
questions.explanation: Forget to do = fail to do (future).

questions.question: I'll never forget ____ (visit) Paris for the first time.
questions.explanation: Forget doing = no memory of (past experience).

Wrong: 'I look forward to see you.' Correct the sentence.
answers: I look forward to seeing you.

questions.explanation: Look forward to + -ing (to is a preposition).
